title: Chameleons
author: Phil-IRI
description: color-changing reptiles that adapt for survival
passage:
Chameleons are extraordinary animals. They are one of the few 
animals that can change their color. This is their way of hiding 
themselves. Chameleons that live in trees are often green. Those 
that live in desert lands are usually brown.
It is also their way of keeping warm. Turning a darker shade 
helps them absorb more heat. They also change colors to send 
messages to other chameleons. Their bright colors may attract 
another chameleon or warn enemies.

questions.question: What is one unique characteristic of chameleons?

options.option: They climb trees fast. They send messages to other animals.

questions.explanation: The passage directly states that chameleons are one of the few animals that can change their color.

questions.question: What will happen to a chameleon on a cold day?

options.option: It will turn a shade lighter.
It will turn a shade darker.

questions.correct_answer: It will turn a shade darker.
questions.explanation: The passage mentions that turning a darker shade helps chameleons absorb more heat, which would be beneficial on a cold day.

questions.question: Changing its color is the chameleon's way of ______.
questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states that changing color is their way of hiding themselves.

questions.question: Chameleons are extraordinary animals. Another word for extraordinary is ______.
questions.explanation: Extraordinary means unusual or exceptional, as reflected by the chameleon's unique color-changing ability.

questions.question: What is the advantage of changing color?

options.option: It can join with other chameleons.
It can hold on to the branch as it climbs.

questions.explanation: The passage states that changing color is the chameleon's way of hiding themselves.

questions.question: The main idea of the selection is

options.option: how chameleons survive in the wild.

questions.explanation: The passage focuses primarily on explaining the various reasons why chameleons change their colors.

questions.question: The best title for this selection is

options.option: How Chameleons Communicate with Other Animals.

questions.explanation: The passage primarily explains the different reasons why chameleons change their color, making this the most suitable title.

title: The Philippine Eagle
author: Phil-IRI
description: endangered national bird facing extinction
passage:
The Philippine Eagle has replaced the maya as our national bird. It 
is one of the three largest and strongest eagles in the world. But it 
is in danger of extinction. Hunting and deforestation have caused 
the number of Philippine Eagles to dwindle. Scientists have tried to 
increase their number by breeding them in captivity. The first eagle 
to be bred in captivity is Pag-asa. At 25 years old, Pag-asa is not yet 
suited to be released to the wild as she has developed dependency 
on her human keeper.

questions.question: The Philippine Eagle is in danger of extinction. It means this type of eagle will eventually ________.
questions.explanation: Extinction means a species no longer exists, so being in danger of extinction means the Philippine Eagle is at risk of disappearing completely.

questions.question: When birds are bred in captivity, they are _________.

options.option: allowed to freely fly in the wide forest.
cared for in a safe environment.

questions.correct_answer: cared for in a safe environment.
questions.explanation: Breeding in captivity refers to raising animals in controlled, protected settings rather than in the wild.

questions.question: What is responsible for the decrease in the number of Philippine Eagles?
questions.explanation: The passage states that hunting and deforestation (both human activities) have caused the number of Philippine Eagles to dwindle.

questions.question: Pag-asa is the name of the first eagle which

options.option: was discovered first in our country.

questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states that Pag-asa is the first eagle to be bred in captivity.

questions.question: What is the problem posed in the selection? The Philippine Eagles _______.

options.option: are in danger of being gone forever
are dying because of a disease

questions.correct_answer: are in danger of being gone forever
questions.explanation: The passage states that the Philippine Eagle is in danger of extinction, which means they could disappear forever.

questions.question: The purpose for writing the selection is to

options.option: invite researchers to study the Philippine eagle.
make the reader proud of the Philippine eagle.
warn the hunters not to harm the Philippine eagle.
raise an alarm about the possible disappearance of the Philippine Eagle.

questions.correct_answer: raise an alarm about the possible disappearance of the Philippine Eagle.
questions.explanation: The passage focuses on the endangered status of the Philippine Eagle and efforts to prevent its extinction.

questions.question: A good title for this selection is
questions.explanation: This title best captures the passage's focus on the endangered status of the Philippine Eagle and the need to preserve it.

title: Home to Millions of Fish
author: Phil-IRI
description: coral reefs as vital underwater ecosystems under threat
passage:
Coral reefs are found in shallow areas of tropical ocean waters.  
They are like beautiful underground gardens that grow in salty 
waters. Millions of fish and sea plants make their home in the reefs 
as these provide a safe sanctuary for them. They allow small fish to 
hide from large predator fish.
But many coral reefs are in trouble. Water pollution is destroying 
many reefs. Tourism likewise harms them. If reefs are damaged, 
we will lose many of our most beautiful fish.

questions.question: Coral reefs are described as underground gardens because _________.

options.option: there are many types of pebbles.

questions.explanation: The passage compares coral reefs to underground gardens, suggesting they contain many sea plants, similar to how gardens contain many plants.

questions.question: Coral reefs provide a safe sanctuary to live for the small fish. A sanctuary is
questions.explanation: In this context, sanctuary refers to a place of safety or shelter, protecting small fish from predators.

questions.question: Which of these bodies of water would have coral reefs?
questions.explanation: The passage states that coral reefs are found in shallow areas of tropical ocean waters, which would be the sea.

questions.question: Why are the small fish safer in the coral reefs than in the open sea?

options.option: The waves are not so big.
It is less likely that the big fish will eat them.

questions.correct_answer: It is less likely that the big fish will eat them.
questions.explanation: The passage states that coral reefs allow small fish to hide from large predator fish, making them safer from being eaten.

questions.question: How is the last paragraph of the selection developed?

options.option: by giving a list of effects.
by enumerating a series of sequenced events.
by stating the main topic and giving examples.
by defining the problem and the possible solution.

questions.correct_answer: by stating the main topic and giving examples.
questions.explanation: The last paragraph states the main topic (coral reefs are in trouble) and gives examples (water pollution, tourism) of what's causing the problem.

questions.question: Which cause of the destruction of coral reefs is mentioned in the last paragraph?

options.option: the strong wind and big waves.
the increasing temperature of the ocean.

questions.explanation: The passage explicitly mentions water pollution as destroying many reefs in the last paragraph.

title: Yawning
author: Phil-IRI
description: involuntary reflex with multiple potential purposes
passage:
What makes us yawn? Yawning is something that we 
cannot control. Even in the mother's womb, eleven-week-old 
babies have been observed to yawn. But why do we do it?
One popular explanation for yawning is that a person may be 
tired or bored. Although many believe this to be true, it cannot 
explain why athletes yawn before an event or why dogs yawn 
before an attack. It is said that yawning is caused by a lack of oxygen and 
excess carbon dioxide. A good example of this is when we yawn 
in groups. We yawn because we are competing for air. Others even believe that we yawn to cool our brains off. 
Cool brains allow us to think more clearly so yawning is said to 
help us become more alert.

questions.question: What is a fact about yawning?

options.option: It is something we cannot control.
It is something only humans do.
It is a result of boredom.

questions.correct_answer: It is something we cannot control.
questions.explanation: The passage directly states that yawning is something that we cannot control.

questions.question: Which of the following might make us yawn?

options.option: being in a small air-conditioned car.

questions.explanation: The passage mentions yawning in groups due to competing for air, which would happen in a crowded room.

questions.question: What does the word "involuntary" mean?
questions.explanation: Involuntary means happening without conscious control, just as the passage describes yawning as something we cannot control.

questions.question: Which of the following may be a benefit of yawning?

options.option: It warns us of possible attacks by dogs.
It provides us the carbon dioxide we need.
It balances the amount of oxygen and carbon dioxide.

questions.explanation: The passage states that some believe we yawn to cool our brains off, presenting this as a potential benefit.

questions.question: According to the selection, what is most likely to happen after we yawn?
questions.explanation: The passage states that cool brains allow us to think more clearly, so yawning is said to help us become more alert.

questions.question: In the selection, how is the word 'compete' used in the phrase "competing for air?"

options.option: struggling to take in some air.

questions.correct_answer: struggling to take in some air.
questions.explanation: In the context of the passage, competing for air means struggling to get enough oxygen in a situation where it's limited.

questions.question: Which of the following shows evidence that "yawning" is "competing for air?"

options.option: The passengers in an elevator yawned.
Several people yawned while picnicking at an open field.
Two people yawned inside a room with air-conditioning.
Three students yawned in a big empty room.

questions.correct_answer: The passengers in an elevator yawned.
questions.explanation: An elevator is typically a small, enclosed space where multiple people would be competing for limited air, supporting the idea of yawning as competing for air.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best response when we see a person/animal yawn?

options.option: Have the person eat a food item that is a good source of energy.
Change the topic of conversation to a more interesting one.
Turn on an electric fan or source of ventilation.
Run away to avoid being attacked.

questions.correct_answer: Turn on an electric fan or source of ventilation.
questions.explanation: Based on the passage's mention of yawning due to competing for air or to cool the brain, providing ventilation would be the most appropriate response.

title: Laughter
author: Phil-IRI
description: natural human response with significant health benefits
passage:
People love to laugh. We love it so much when there are 
jokes, jobs, and shows that are made to make us laugh. Even 
though laughing seems natural, not many species are able to do 
so. Laughing involves the performance of rhythmic, involuntary 
movements, and the production of sounds. We are able to 
laugh using fifteen facial muscles, our respiratory system, and 
sometimes even our tear ducts. We are lucky that we are able to laugh because there is 
strong evidence that laughter can help improve health. Laughter 
boosts the immune system and adds another layer of protection 
from disease. Since laughter also increases blood flow, it 
improves the function of blood vessels that helps protect the 
heart. Laughter also relaxes the whole body by relieving tension 
and stress. Finally, laughter also brings out the body's natural 
feel-good chemicals that promote well-being.

questions.question: What is laughing?

options.option: It is the voluntary reception of sounds.
It is the voluntary production of sounds.
It is the involuntary production of sounds.
It is the voluntary use of our facial muscles.

questions.correct_answer: It is the involuntary production of sounds.
questions.explanation: The passage describes laughing as involving rhythmic, involuntary movements and the production of sounds.

questions.question: What does the statement, "There are jokes, jobs, and shows that are made

options.option: Laughter is something we have to work at.
Comedy shows are good sources of income.
Laughter is an important part of our life.
Jokes and comedy shows are expensive ways to make us laugh.

questions.correct_answer: Laughter is an important part of our life.
questions.explanation: The passage begins by stating that people love to laugh so much that various forms of entertainment are created specifically to make us laugh, indicating its importance in our lives.

questions.question: In what way does laughing prevent us from getting sick?

options.option: It lets us have full use of our respiratory system.
It helps boost our immune system.
It allows us to use our tear ducts.

questions.correct_answer: It helps boost our immune system.
questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states that laughter boosts the immune system and adds another layer of protection from disease.

questions.question: If laughter increases blood flow, which body system does it help?
questions.explanation: Blood flow is part of the circulatory system, so when laughter improves blood flow and blood vessel function, it's helping the circulatory system.

questions.question: Which word CANNOT be used to describe laughing?
questions.explanation: The passage specifically describes laughing as involving involuntary movements, which is the opposite of voluntary.

questions.question: Which of the following facts about laughter would be helpful to a

options.option: Laughter keeps tension and stress away.
Laughter may help protect us from diseases.
Laughter brings out the 'feel good' chemicals.

questions.correct_answer: Laughter keeps tension and stress away.
questions.explanation: The passage states that laughter relaxes the whole body by relieving tension and stress, which would be particularly helpful for someone experiencing stress.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best title for the selection?

options.option: Laughter is what sets humans apart.

questions.explanation: This title best captures the main focus of the passage on the health benefits of laughter, including immune system boosting, cardiovascular benefits, and stress relief.

questions.question: Which of the following would be the most ideal place to spread the good
questions.explanation: Given the passage's emphasis on laughter's health benefits, a hospital would be the most ideal place to spread this information, as it could help patients' recovery and well-being.

title: Effects of Anger
author: Phil-IRI
description: physical manifestations and potential positive uses of anger
passage:
Anger is often viewed as harmful. It does not only affect the 
person feeling this anger but those around him or her. As these 
feelings get stronger, changes occur in our body. Our faces turn 
red and carry a frown. Our teeth are clenched and our hands are 
closed tight. Our breathing becomes heavy and this makes our 
heart beat faster. Our shoulder and neck muscles become stiff 
and our blood pressure begins to rise. All these things happen 
because our body is preparing for something. It is preparing for 
action. However, this action does not have to be harmful. 
People are often guilty about feeling angry. But, anger can 
be viewed positively. Feelings of anger tell you that something is 
not right and that something needs to change. The challenge lies 
in making sure that actions resulting from anger will help rather 
than harm. Expressing our feelings can help others understand 
the source of our anger rather than fear its consequences.

questions.question: Which is NOT an observed change in our body when we get angry?
questions.explanation: The passage states that our breathing becomes heavy when angry, not slow, so this option contradicts the information provided.

questions.question: In the sentence, "Changes occur in our body," which of the following words is a synonym for the word occur?
questions.explanation: In this context, the word 'occur' means to happen or take place, making 'happen' the closest synonym.

questions.question: Why do people sometimes feel guilty for being angry?

options.option: Anger is not a feeling you should show to other people.
Anger may cause us to create positive change in the world.
Anger may cause us to be motivated to act on something.

questions.explanation: The passage states that anger affects not only the person feeling it but those around them, suggesting people feel guilty because they worry about hurting others.

questions.question: Which of these actions is based on anger as a positive form of expression?

options.option: identifying the root of the problem.
keeping our emotions bottled up inside of us.

questions.correct_answer: identifying the root of the problem.
questions.explanation: The passage explains that anger can be positive when it tells us something is not right and needs to change, which involves identifying the root problem.

questions.question: Which of these actions are based on anger as a form of motivation?

options.option: asking the person we are angry at to think of how the problem can be resolved.
giving the person that we are angry at the silent treatment.
kicking a chair aside and screaming out loud.
seeking the help of a third person to side with you.

questions.correct_answer: asking the person we are angry at to think of how the problem can be resolved.
questions.explanation: This action aligns with the passage's emphasis on using anger constructively to create positive change and help others understand the source of anger.

questions.question: What is one benefit of feeling angry?

options.option: It provides a form of exercise for our heart and blood vessels.
It prepares us for future occasions that we might feel angry.
It serves as a signal that something is not right.
It changes how our mind works.

questions.correct_answer: It serves as a signal that something is not right.
questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states that feelings of anger tell you that something is not right and that something needs to change.

questions.question: In the selection, what is the meaning of the word "challenge?"

options.option: It refers to a task that is new.
It refers to a task that is different.
It refers to a task that is assigned to us.
It refers to a task that is difficult to do.

questions.correct_answer: It refers to a task that is difficult to do.
questions.explanation: In the context of the passage, the challenge of making sure actions from anger help rather than harm implies difficulty in achieving that goal.

questions.question: In the selection, which trait would be most helpful when trying to use our anger in a positive way?
questions.explanation: The passage emphasizes expressing feelings to help others understand the source of anger, which requires honesty about one's emotions and their causes.

title: Dreams
author: Phil-IRI
description: brain activity during sleep that may serve multiple functions
passage:
We often say "Sweet dreams," but have you ever wondered 
why we dream? Some say that dreaming is our brain's way 
of exercising. While we sleep, our brain may be testing the 
connections and pathways to see if they are working well. Others 
believe that dreaming is our brain's way of sorting out problems. 
Problems that have not been addressed during the day are 
sometimes resolved in our sleep. Yet another explanation is 
that dreaming is our brain's way of fixing and organizing all the 
information we have. While sleeping, our brains have a chance 
to sort out the information that we want to keep from the stuff we 
no longer want. Still another idea is that dreams are just another 
form of thinking. Will we ever get to know the answer to this 
question? Maybe we should sleep on it.
explanation: This passage explores different theories about why humans dream, including brain exercise, problem-solving, information organization, and an alternative form of thinking.

questions.question: What do people usually say to one another before sleeping?
questions.explanation: The passage begins with the phrase 'We often say "Sweet dreams,"' which directly answers this literal question.

questions.question: Why is dreaming compared to exercise in this selection?

options.option: A. Both are ways of helping the brain function better.
B. Both make us relaxed and rested.
C. Both happen while we are still awake.
D. Both happen only at night time.

questions.correct_answer: A. Both are ways of helping the brain function better.
questions.explanation: The passage states that dreaming may be the brain's way of exercising, 'testing the connections and pathways to see if they are working well.'

questions.question: According to the selection, one reason why people dream is to

options.option: A. have problems that we did not have during the day.
B. solve problems that we have not addressed during the day.
C. allow our bodies to move around while sleeping.
D. pretend that we are dreaming when we are actually awake.

questions.correct_answer: B. solve problems that we have not addressed during the day.
questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states that 'Problems that have not been addressed during the day are sometimes resolved in our sleep.'

questions.question: Which of the following is a problem that may be solved while sleeping?

options.option: A. how to tell a certain person to stop talking too much.
B. how to be kind to animals.
C. how to solve a mathematical equation
D. how to be careful when crossing the street.

questions.correct_answer: C. how to solve a mathematical equation
questions.explanation: Since the passage mentions problem solving during sleep, solving a mathematical equation represents a logical application of this concept.

questions.question: According to the selection, dreams might also help us
questions.explanation: The passage states that during sleep 'our brains have a chance to sort out the information that we want to keep,' suggesting dreams help retain important information.

questions.question: In the selection, what does "Sort out information" mean?
questions.explanation: The passage explains sorting as separating 'information that we want to keep from the stuff we no longer want,' which involves both remembering and forgetting.

questions.question: Why does the writer end with "Maybe we should sleep on it."?

options.option: A. To convey that we need to sleep for us to dream.
B. To convey that sleeping is important for us to think well.
C. To convey a sense of uncertainty about the main ideas.
D. To convey the idea that we all need to sleep.

questions.correct_answer: C. To convey a sense of uncertainty about the main ideas.
questions.explanation: The writer ends with this phrase after asking if we'll ever know the answer, showing uncertainty while cleverly using a phrase about sleep to conclude an article about dreams.

questions.question: The selection answers the question

options.option: B. Why do we have problems?

questions.explanation: The passage begins by asking 'have you ever wondered why we dream?' and then explores various theories explaining the purpose of dreams.

title: Rocks from Outer Space
author: Phil-IRI
description: different terms for space rocks and their behaviors
passage:
The pieces of rocks that come from outer space have three 
names: meteor, meteorite, and meteoroid. A meteoroid is a piece of matter moving in space.
It moves as fast as 40 miles a second. It may be large or small. Most 
meteoroids are smaller than a grain of sand. As a meteoroid comes into the air near the earth, it catches 
fire. Most meteoroids burn up before they hit the earth. The flash of light from the burning meteoroid is called a meteor. 
If a piece of meteoroid falls to the ground, it is called a meteorite. People have studied these rocks for many years.  
They wanted to research ways to keep meteoroids from making holes 
in spacecrafts. Thick walls may help. Or perhaps spacecrafts 
can be covered with a metal skin that will seal itself.
explanation: This passage explains the differences between meteoroids, meteors, and meteorites, describing their characteristics and how scientists are studying ways to protect spacecraft from them.

questions.question: Where do the meteoroids originate?

options.option: A. from the outer layer of the earth.

questions.explanation: The passage begins by stating that 'The pieces of rocks that come from outer space have three names,' directly identifying their origin.

questions.question: A meteoroid catches fire when

options.option: B. it falls to the ground.
C. it collides with a spacecraft.
D. it comes into the air near the earth.

questions.correct_answer: D. it comes into the air near the earth.
questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states that 'As a meteoroid comes into the air near the earth, it catches fire.'

questions.question: When is a meteoroid dangerous?

options.option: A. when it falls to earth and burns down houses.
B. when it makes holes in a spacecraft.
C. when it hits the airplanes.

questions.correct_answer: B. when it makes holes in a spacecraft.
questions.explanation: The passage mentions that researchers wanted 'to keep meteoroids from making holes in spacecrafts,' identifying this as a specific danger.

questions.question: The rocks from outer space are studied to find out ________.

options.option: A. the time that they fall on earth.
B. how these rocks could be used.
C. how to avoid their fall on earth.
D. how to keep them from making holes in spacecraft.

questions.correct_answer: D. how to keep them from making holes in spacecraft.
questions.explanation: The passage states that 'People have studied these rocks for many years. They wanted to research ways to keep meteoroids from making holes in spacecrafts.'

questions.question: What is true of meteoroids, meteorites, and meteors?

options.option: C. They all fall to the earth.
D. They all turn into balls of fire.

questions.explanation: The passage begins by describing them as 'pieces of rocks that come from outer space,' establishing their fundamental nature.

questions.question: When one sees a flash of light in space, he may exclaim _______.
questions.explanation: The passage defines a meteor as 'The flash of light from the burning meteoroid,' so seeing such a flash would correctly be identified as a meteor.

questions.question: Which is the best definition of a meteorite?

options.option: A. a flash of light from a burning meteoroid.
B. a piece of meteoroid that falls to the ground.
C. a piece of rock from outer space that hit a spacecraft.
D. a piece of rock from outer space that burn up before hitting the ground.

questions.correct_answer: B. a piece of meteoroid that falls to the ground.
questions.explanation: The passage directly states that 'If a piece of meteoroid falls to the ground, it is called a meteorite.'

questions.question: In the sentence, "They research ways to keep meteoroids from making holes in the spacecraft," another word for research is ______.
questions.explanation: In this context, 'research' means to investigate or examine carefully, which is synonymous with 'study.'

title: Beetles
author: Phil-IRI
description: highly adaptable insects with specialized body structures
passage:
Beetles can adapt to any kind of environment. They can be 
found crawling, burrowing, flying, and swimming on every part 
of the earth except the ocean. Why do beetles survive well on 
our planet? First, they have tough compact bodies. These help 
them hide, find food, and lay eggs in places where other insects 
could never go. Almost all beetles have tough front wings which are colorful 
and carry beautiful patterns. These wings also act as suit of 
armor to protect the beetles' transparent hind wings which are 
used for flying. Beetles have mouth parts designed for chewing different 
food. They eat other insects, animal dung, and even cloth. They 
also feed on the bark, leaves, flowers, and fruits of any kind 
of plant. They can even chew around the stems of poisonous 
plants to let the deadly sap drain.
explanation: This passage describes how beetles have successfully adapted to survive in diverse environments through their specialized body structures and varied diet.

questions.question: In which of these places WON'T you find beetles?
questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states that beetles can be found 'on every part of the earth except the ocean,' which is the sea.

questions.question: In the sentence Beetles can adapt to any kind of environment, which is a synonym of adapt?
questions.explanation: In this context, 'adapt' means to adjust to new conditions, which is synonymous with 'get used to.'

questions.question: What pair of words describe the beetles' front wings?
questions.explanation: The passage describes the front wings as 'tough' and 'colorful' with beautiful patterns.

questions.question: What is the use of the beetles' hind wings?

options.option: A. for protecting the front wings

questions.explanation: The passage states that beetles have 'transparent hind wings which are used for flying.'

questions.question: Which of the following states the main idea of this selection?

options.option: A. reasons why beetles can survive anywhere.
B. places where one can find beetles
C. the compact body of the beetles
D. the food that beetles eat

questions.correct_answer: A. reasons why beetles can survive anywhere.
questions.explanation: The passage focuses on explaining why beetles are so adaptable, with details about their body structures and feeding habits supporting this main idea.

questions.question: What action of the beetle means making a hole in the ground?
questions.explanation: Burrowing refers to digging or making holes in the ground, which is one of the ways beetles navigate their environment.

questions.question: The front wings of most beetles ______________.
questions.explanation: The passage states that the front wings 'act as suit of armor to protect the beetles' transparent hind wings.'

questions.question: If someone says, "You eat like a beetle" it means that _____________.

options.option: A. You are a picky eater.
D. You eat very little amount of food.

questions.explanation: The passage explains that beetles eat a wide variety of foods including insects, dung, cloth, and various plant parts, suggesting they can consume almost anything.

title: Just how fast
author: Phil-IRI
description: comparative speeds of different objects and phenomena
passage:
Many things around us move at different rates. Glaciers, 
which are frozen rivers of snow, move less than one foot in a 
day. A box turtle travels about ten feet per minute, while a snail 
travels five inches per hour. A chimney swift flies almost ninety 
miles per hour. This is the fastest speed recorded for any living 
creature. A hydroplane skims across the top of the water at nearly 
300 miles an hour. Some racing cars travel more than 500 miles 
per hour. The wind in a tornado may move at 600 miles per hour 
but sound waves are faster with a speed of up to 740 miles per 
hour. The Earth moves around the sun at 67,000 miles per hour. 
At 186,000 miles per second, light is faster! Science has yet to 
discover anything that would surpass this speed.
explanation: This passage compares the speeds of various objects and phenomena, from the extremely slow movement of glaciers to the incredibly fast speed of light, highlighting the vast range of motion speeds in our universe.

questions.question: Which living creature has the highest recorded speed?
questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states that a chimney swift flies at 'almost ninety miles per hour' and notes that 'This is the fastest speed recorded for any living creature.'

questions.question: Among the following, which has the slowest rate of movement?
questions.explanation: The passage states that glaciers 'move less than one foot in a day' while a snail moves 'five inches per hour,' making glaciers the slowest of the options listed.

questions.question: What does this statement mean? "Science has yet to discover anything that would surpass the speed of light."

options.option: A. Someday, something faster than light will be discovered.
B. Of all moving objects, only light waves will never slow down.
C. Among all things, light waves will always have the fastest speed.
D. Of all that has been observed, light waves have the fastest speed.

questions.correct_answer: D. Of all that has been observed, light waves have the fastest speed.
questions.explanation: The statement indicates that so far in scientific discovery, nothing has been found to be faster than light, meaning light currently holds the record for fastest observed speed.

questions.question: Which among these statements is true?

options.option: A. A box turtle is faster than a snail.
B. A snail is faster than a box turtle.
C. A hydroplane is slower than a glacier.
D. A glacier is faster than a hydroplane.

questions.correct_answer: A. A box turtle is faster than a snail.
questions.explanation: According to the passage, a box turtle travels 'about ten feet per minute' while a snail travels only 'five inches per hour,' making the turtle faster.

questions.question: Which among these statements is NOT supported by the selection?

options.option: A. Tornadoes are around double the speed of a hydroplane.
B. Sound waves are about two times the speed of light waves.
C. A hydroplane is about half the speed of the wind in a tornado.
D. The speed of light is faster than the speed of the earth's rotation.

questions.correct_answer: B. Sound waves are about two times the speed of light waves.
questions.explanation: The passage states that sound waves travel at 'up to 740 miles per hour' while light travels at '186,000 miles per second,' which is dramatically faster than sound, not twice as slow.

questions.question: "Science has yet to discover anything that would surpass this speed." The synonym of surpass is ____________.
questions.explanation: In this context, 'surpass' means to go beyond or be greater than, which is synonymous with 'exceed.'

questions.question: Which among these statements is an opinion?

options.option: A. Sound waves move faster than the wind.
B. There will never be anything faster than light.
C. Many things differ in their rates of movement.
D. The earth orbits the sun at 67,000 miles per hour.

questions.correct_answer: B. There will never be anything faster than light.
questions.explanation: This statement makes a prediction about the future that cannot be proven with current evidence, making it an opinion rather than a fact.

questions.question: Which sentence states the main idea of the selection?

options.option: A. A hydroplane skims across the top of the water at nearly 300 miles an hour.
B. There are many things found around us that move at different rates.
C. The chimney swift has the fastest recorded speed among living things.
D. The Earth orbits the sun at 67,000 miles per hour but light moves faster.

questions.correct_answer: B. There are many things found around us that move at different rates.
questions.explanation: This is the opening sentence of the passage and sets up the theme that is developed throughout with examples of objects moving at various speeds.

title: Flying Rocks
author: Phil-IRI
description: asteroids and meteoroids in our solar system
passage:
There are rocks in our Solar System that never flocked together to 
form planets. Larger ones called asteroids gather in the Asteroid 
Belt, a strip found between Mars and Jupiter. Some asteroids 
don't move along this belt but have paths that bring them close 
to the earth. These are called Apollo Asteroids.
There may be half a million asteroids whose diameters 
are bigger than one kilometer. The largest asteroid is over 1000 
kilometers across. It is speculated that many asteroids were 
once larger but they collided with each other and became small 
fragments. Unlike asteroids, meteoroids are small rocky bodies, that 
are scattered in space and do not orbit the sun. They cross 
the Earth's orbit and are often seen burning up in the Earth's 
atmosphere at night. The faint flashes of light they make are 
called shooting stars.
explanation: This passage explains the differences between asteroids and meteoroids in our solar system, describing their characteristics, locations, and what happens when meteoroids enter Earth's atmosphere.

questions.question: What are asteroids?

options.option: A. Large fragments of rock in the Solar System.
B. Large fragments of rock that circle the moon.
C. Small fragments of rock that do not circle the sun.
D. Small fragments of rock that do not circle the planets.

questions.correct_answer: A. Large fragments of rock in the Solar System.
questions.explanation: The passage describes asteroids as 'Larger ones' referring to rocks in our Solar System that never formed planets.

questions.question: What are meteoroids?

options.option: A. Large fragments of rock that circle the sun.
B. Large fragments of rock that circle the planets.
C. Small bits of rock that do not circle the sun.
D. Small bits of rock that do not cross the planets' orbits.

questions.correct_answer: C. Small bits of rock that do not circle the sun.
questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states that 'meteoroids are small rocky bodies, that are scattered in space and do not orbit the sun.'

questions.question: Which among the following statements is NOT true?

options.option: A. Some asteroids move close to the earth.
B. Large rocks flock together in the Asteroid Belt.
C. All rocks in our Solar System have formed planets.
D. The Asteroid Belt is found between Mars and Jupiter.

questions.correct_answer: C. All rocks in our Solar System have formed planets.
questions.explanation: The very first sentence of the passage states that 'There are rocks in our Solar System that never flocked together to form planets,' directly contradicting this statement.

questions.question: "It is speculated that many asteroids were once larger." What does the word speculated mean?
questions.explanation: In this context, 'speculated' means to form a theory without firm evidence, which is most closely aligned with 'guessed.'

questions.question: What is a possible reason behind the fact that asteroids are not anymore as large as they were first thought to be?

options.option: A. They could have shrunk when they got closer to the sun.
B. They could have hit one another and broken into pieces.
C. They could have burned up and eventually become smaller.
D. They could have rammed into some planet and broken apart.

questions.correct_answer: B. They could have hit one another and broken into pieces.
questions.explanation: The passage states that 'many asteroids were once larger but they collided with each other and became small fragments,' supporting this explanation.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE of asteroids and meteoroids?

options.option: A. Both asteroids and meteoroids are composed of rocky particles found in the Solar System.
B. Both asteroids and meteoroids circle the Earth and can be seen as faint flashes of light.
C. Both asteroids and meteoroids are scattered randomly across in space and do not orbit the sun.
D. Both asteroids and meteoroids can be seen in a belt of rocks between Jupiter and Mars.

questions.correct_answer: A. Both asteroids and meteoroids are composed of rocky particles found in the Solar System.
questions.explanation: The passage describes both asteroids and meteoroids as types of rocks in our Solar System, with asteroids being 'larger ones' and meteoroids being 'small rocky bodies.'

questions.question: Many asteroids must have collided with one another. What is a synonym of the word "collided?"
questions.explanation: In this context, 'collided' means to hit with force, which is most closely matched by 'crashed into.'

questions.question: If you see faint flashes of light in the night sky, which of the following could have happened?

options.option: A. Meteoroids have just crossed the earth's orbit and burned up.
B. Flames shoot up from the sun and come closer to the earth.
C. Meteoroids have just crossed paths with the sun and burned up.
D. There are moments when the earth orbits a lot closer to the sun.

questions.correct_answer: A. Meteoroids have just crossed the earth's orbit and burned up.
questions.explanation: The passage states that meteoroids 'cross the Earth's orbit and are often seen burning up in the Earth's atmosphere at night. The faint flashes of light they make are called shooting stars.'

title: Palace
author: Dorothy Vena Johnson
description: a poem about the wonder of seashells
explanation: This poem personifies seashells as magical palaces containing the ocean's mysteries and sounds.
passage:
A seashell is a palace
Where many echoes dwell,
And when I listen to them
I know them quite well.
They are like the ocean's roar
Where the sea shells buried deep
Learns why the sea is always salty,
And spooky shadows creep.

questions.question: What is described in the poem?
questions.explanation: This question asks students to identify that the poem describes seashells and their qualities.

questions.question: Where do sea shells learn that the sea is salty?
questions.explanation: This question tests comprehension of the poem's imagery about seashells buried deep in the ocean.

title: A little girl
author: Ada Greiner Marks
description: a lyrical portrait of childhood innocence
explanation: This poem paints a detailed portrait of a little girl, using vivid imagery to capture her physical appearance and cheerful spirit.
passage:
She is little, she is dimpled
Her hair is yellow corn
On her cheeks are many smudges
And her pinafore is torn.
Her eyes are dancing waters
On a deep, midsummer day,
Yet her mouth will turn to pouting
In a most capricious way.
But her laughter is as joyous
As the little winds that run
On amber feet across the seas
Of wheat fields in the sun.
And her laughter is as delightful
As a carillon of bells
In an ancient, wooded tower
Where a charming fairy dwells.
Hers is the laughter from the spirit
Melodious and mild
All the angels pause a moment
For the laughter of a child.

questions.question: Who is described in this poem?
questions.explanation: This question checks basic comprehension that the poem is describing a little girl.

questions.question: Have you seen such a little girl?
questions.explanation: This question encourages personal connection to the poem's description.

questions.question: To what is her hair compared?
questions.explanation: This question tests attention to the metaphor comparing her hair to yellow corn.

questions.question: Her eyes?
questions.explanation: This question checks comprehension of the metaphor comparing her eyes to dancing waters.

questions.question: Her laughter?
questions.explanation: This question tests understanding of multiple similes describing the girl's laughter.

questions.question: What would you feel if you were with a girl like this little girl? Why?
questions.explanation: This question encourages empathetic response and personal reflection on the poem.

title: Spider Webs
author: James S. Tippet
description: nature's delicate morning artwork
explanation: This poem describes the magical collaboration between spiders and morning mist in creating beautiful webs adorned with dewdrops.
passage:
The spiders were busy last night,
From every fence and tree
They hung their lacy webs
For all the world to see.
The mist was busy too;
In the stillness of the night
It strung the spider webs with pearls
To catch the morning light.
One spider wove a web
Like frost on a window pane;
Another one spun a single thread
That looks like jeweled chain.
Motionless hang the webs,
By the quiet sunbeam kissed;
A fairy world was made last night
By the spiders and the mist.

questions.question: What did the spiders do in the night?
questions.explanation: This question tests basic comprehension about the spiders weaving webs during the night.

questions.question: What did the mist do?
questions.explanation: This question checks understanding of how the mist adorned the webs with dewdrops like pearls.

questions.question: What were some of the webs compared to?
questions.explanation: This question tests recognition of the similes comparing webs to frost on a window pane and jeweled chains.

title: My dear Jasmine
author: Gina Frio-Nobleza
description: a conversation between mother and daughter about life lessons
explanation: This story depicts a thoughtful conversation between a mother and her daughter Jasmine, where the mother shares important life lessons about sacrifice and appreciation.
passage:
I heard my happy little daughter sing a happy tune to what she was watching on TV. A smile gave her the puffy cheeks and sparkling eyes as she focused her attention on it. "Mother! Do you like lambs?" Jasmine asked me. I put down my phone and glasses, then glanced at her. "Of course. They are fluffy and adorable. Who wouldn't?" I replied. "But why bad men cut their fur?" she asked.
"No, my child. Sheep or adult lamb's fur is used to make clothes. Don't worry, their fur usually grows back. But Mr. Edward isn't a bad man, okay?" I explained and reasoned with her. Though she was hesitant, she agreed. A soft, endearing aura filled the cream walls of the room. The resounding of the fans spinning along with Jasmine's noticeable breathing, was very calming. She finally took her first move and spun around gleefully. She danced and sang along to the song of the birds and the stupendous rhythm of the trees as they swayed against their will. She twirled and would make expressive poses as the song went on.
I sat back down at our table and took the newspaper. I opened the gray, folded paper and read through the headlines. "This is really boring." I flipped another one, "How did these students convert noise to electricity? If my old classmates were to use this, we would have infinite electricity."
"To see is to believe. Is that true, Mother?" Jasmine sweetly asked. "I believe so. Seeing something means it is true, so believe in it. Do you understand?" I asked her, and she nodded.
"My dear, let me tell you something. A word and advice." I pat her back and she only responded with a small "sure". She sat down on the maroon sofa with intricate tiny flower designs. I took a seat on the opposite to the sofa she was sitting on. "Many are sacrificing just to give other people a better life. Let us appreciate them."
Jasmine blinked, before clasping her hands together. "What do you mean?" she asked.
"For example, sheep give us comfortable sweaters. Scientists invent and discover things for the development of our society. In battles, there are people who are brave enough to fight for their country. Just like your father. He was a brave man." I ruffled her hair.
She smiled adoringly. "I understand, Mother. One day, I'll help you out, too!" she exclaimed and hugged me. "As you wish, my dear," I replied.

questions.question: Who narrated the story?
questions.explanation: The story is told from the first-person perspective of Jasmine's mother.

questions.question: How did Jasmine and her mother spend their time together?

options.option: They both sang their favorite song.
They stayed home and did their chores.
They shared and discussed their ideas.
They watched their favorite TV program.

questions.correct_answer: They shared and discussed their ideas.
questions.explanation: Throughout the story, the mother and Jasmine engage in thoughtful conversation, sharing ideas and life lessons.

questions.question: How do you describe Jasmine's mother?

options.option: She loved to read and sing.
She was loving, sweet and logical.

questions.correct_answer: She was loving, sweet and logical.
questions.explanation: The mother shows love by engaging with her daughter, sweetness in her interactions, and logic in her explanations.

questions.question: Jasmine was observant and inquisitive. Which of the sentences below supports this idea?

options.option: She knew that her father was a brave soldier.
She kept on interfering with other people's lives.
She could sing many songs and danced with their tunes.
She was curious about the things she watched and heard.

questions.correct_answer: She was curious about the things she watched and heard.
questions.explanation: Jasmine asks multiple questions throughout the story, demonstrating her curiosity and inquisitive nature.

questions.question: What did the word "sacrifice" mean for Jasmine?

options.option: helping out her mother one day

questions.correct_answer: helping out her mother one day
questions.explanation: Jasmine responds to her mother's lesson about sacrifice by promising to help her mother in the future.

title: The Nasty Owl
author: Phil-IRI
description: a story about treating others as you want to be treated
explanation: This fable tells the story of a mean owl who treated forest animals poorly, only to receive the same treatment in return.
passage:
As the brilliant red and orange light in the sky faded, the Owl's hooting echoed through the forest. She was now ready to hunt. When the soft glowing light appeared in the sky, the Owl began her sweet slumber while other animals in the forest started their daily activities.
One sunny day, the Owl dozed in the hollow of an old tree. The three blind mice passed by and joyfully sang. The Owl was annoyed and shouted at the three mice. "Stay away from here foolish mice, you have no respect," she angrily said. Disheartened, the mice stopped singing and went away.
Little Rabbit, who lived nearby, took out his drum that his parents gave him for his birthday. He was excited to try it. He went out from his hole and started beating his drum in perfect rhythm, while he stomped his feet. This awakened and irritated the Owl. The Owl threw a twig at Little Rabbit and said, "Hey, stay away from here, disgusting rabbit, you have no respect," she uttered. Saddened by the scolding of the Owl, Little Rabbit went away.
The five little monkeys were preparing for their sports competition in school. They had to strengthen their muscles. They swung in the trees and happily screeched, gibbered and whooped. They reached the old tree where the Owl was sleeping. Enraged with the noise, the Owl went out from her hole and stared angrily at the monkeys. She said, "Stay away from here, you are all annoying and inconsiderate". The five little monkeys were hurt by the Owl's words so, they went away.
The same thing happened to every animal that passed by the old tree where the Owl slept. She drove everyone away and hurled them with nasty and harsh words.
Night time came. All animals in the forest went home to rest and sleep. On the other hand, the Owl woke up to start her hunting activity. As he flew around the forest, her "Hooooh hooooh!" resonated in the quiet forest. All animals woke up and went out of their homes.
"You're disgusting, you have no respect," the three blind mice exclaimed.
"You are foolish, you have no respect," the rabbit added.
"You are inconsiderate, you have no respect," the five monkeys shouted.
Other animals joined in cursing the Owl. "Stay away from here, nasty Owl! Stay away from this forest," they yelled.
Those offensively impolite words from the animals made her spirit low. She felt sad and guilty. She flew away and never came back to that forest anymore.

questions.question: What did the owl do during the day?
questions.explanation: The passage clearly states that the owl slept during the day and hunted at night.

questions.question: How would you describe the owl in the story?
questions.explanation: The owl consistently speaks rudely to other animals and uses harsh, disrespectful language.

questions.question: Why do you think the owl flew away and did not come back to that forest?

options.option: He was guilty of what he did.
He could not sleep well in that forest.

questions.correct_answer: He was guilty of what he did.
questions.explanation: The story states that the owl felt sad and guilty after experiencing the same treatment she had given others.

questions.question: If you were the owl, how would you handle noisy animals that disturbed your sleep? Share your answers to the class.
questions.explanation: This question encourages students to think about alternative, more respectful approaches to solving conflicts.

title: The missing kittens
author: Gina Frio-Nobleza
description: a story about assumptions and misunderstandings
explanation: This story teaches the dangers of making false assumptions as a mother cat wrongly accuses a dog of stealing her kittens.
passage:
Ming, the cat, gave birth to three adorable furry kittens. The first one was pure white with blue eyes, the second was orange with some gray stripes with yellow eyes, and the third looked exactly as its mother, all black with emerald eyes. She placed them inside the shoebox in the linen room. Doggie the dog came near her and sniffed her kittens. "I am warning you Doggie. Never touch my children or else you will be in trouble," she uttered. Doggie went away, his tail curved between his legs.
The night was dark and quiet. Ming prowled through the attic and waited for any mouse to come out. She was yearning for a fresh prey to regain her strength which she lost in giving birth to her kittens. Suddenly, she heard a squeak. A big mouse came out from its hole. She ran after it and grabbed its tail. It struggled to free itself from the cat's paw, but to no avail.
"Please, don't eat me. My children are waiting for my safe return. They are still too small and couldn't manage to live without a mother," the mouse begged. Ming's heart was touched by the mouse's words. She remembered her children and empathized with the mouse. She unclenched her claws and the mouse ran away.
She stayed there the whole night, but no more mouse came out. Dawn came with the crowing of the roosters. She smelled something from the kitchen. Her masters were preparing breakfast and she knew that her regular supply of milk would be ready, too. She licked the milk in the bowl until there was no more left. She decided to go back to her kittens. "They might be hungry," she said. "I need to breastfeed them."
She hurried her steps, but when she looked at the box, it was empty. "My kittens are missing, my kittens are missing!" she let out an angry cry. She angrily looked at Doggie who was still sleeping on some rugs, his body curled. Ming stiffened her rear legs and moved toward the dog. She growled and scratched the poor dog on its face. Startled, Doggie woke up in pain and gave a deafening bark. This fueled the cat's anger. She clawed and bit him. "Stop! Stop!" said the confused dog. "I won't stop unless you show me my kittens!," the cat shouted. "But I..." the dog interrupted. He did not finish what he was going to say when Ming stopped. The purring of tiny kittens was heard.
Ming left the wounded dog and followed the sound. She peered through the slightly opened door and saw her master's children cuddling her kittens. She meowed! "Oh, hello Ming, looking for your kittens? Here they are, we just borrowed them for a while!" exclaimed one of the children.

questions.question: How would you describe the three kittens?

options.option: They were all white with green eyes.

questions.explanation: The passage clearly describes the three kittens with distinct colors: white with blue eyes, orange with gray stripes and yellow eyes, and black with emerald eyes.

questions.question: Why did the mother cat warn the dog?

options.option: The dog attempted to attack the cat.
The cat knew that the dog did not like her kittens.
They had previous quarrel that wasn't resolved.
She was suspicious that the dog would harm her kittens.

questions.correct_answer: She was suspicious that the dog would harm her kittens.
questions.explanation: The cat was being protective and suspicious when the dog approached to sniff her kittens.

questions.question: Why did the cat let go the mouse?
questions.explanation: The cat empathized with the mouse as a fellow mother when it pleaded about its children waiting for its return.

questions.question: Was the cat right on his accusations to the dog? Why or why not?

options.option: Yes, the dog made a guilty bark.
Yes, the dogs naturally hate cats.
No, it was the mouse who stole the cat.
No, it was the children who took the kittens.

questions.correct_answer: No, it was the children who took the kittens.
questions.explanation: The cat was wrong to accuse the dog as the story reveals it was the human children who had taken the kittens.

title: The Legend of Dragon Fruit
author: Gina Frio-Nobleza
description: a story about friendship, betrayal, and transformation
explanation: This folk legend tells the origin story of the dragon fruit, explaining how it came from a dragon who was betrayed while trying to protect his friend.
passage:
There was a time in the history of Lu Shing Empire that dragons lived in harmony with humans. These winged, four-legged animals were capable of breathing fire and hoarding gold, which they shared with the people. Everyone felt secured and enjoyed a prosperous life.
Drago, a dragon with pinkish-red skin and light green scales served the emperor and his family. He was especially dear to the emperor's daughter, Celestine, who enjoyed riding on Drago's back as he flew her to magical lands.
"Oh, Drago! I love you! We've been to many places, yet you haven't taken me to the place where other dragons hid the treasures. Can you take me there, please?" pleaded Celestine.
"But, it's forbidden," Drago replied.
"Please Drago, I am just curious. Promise! I won't tell anyone," Celestine insisted. Drago could not resist the Princess' charm, so he agreed.
A soldier overheard their conversation and reported it back to the emperor. "If I could have all those treasures, this empire would be the most powerful in the world. Everyone would worship me like a god!" the greedy emperor exclaimed. He ordered his soldier to follow Drago and his daughter.
In no time, Drago and Celestine reached a big cave on top of the Seventh Mountain. Celestine's eyes widened and her jaws dropped when she saw a gigantic heap of gold. The hoard-guarding dragon was lying on top of gold and was soundly sleeping.
"Let's go, Celestine. I would be in so much trouble if any of my kind finds out that I took you here," Drago nervously said.
They were about to leave when the emperor, armed with a battalion of soldiers, arrived. They aimed their spears at the sleeping dragon. Before it could even wake, hundreds of spears and arrows landed on its body that brought to its instant death. Enraged with what he witnessed, Drago exhaled a flaming fire toward the emperor and the soldiers' direction.
"Drago, please stop. He is my father and they are my people," pleaded the princess with tears streaming down her face. Drago bent his knees on the ground as a sign of retreat when a dagger hit his right eye.
It came from the emperor. Bleeding in pain, Drago still managed to release a fiery breath which burned the emperor to death. The remaining soldiers finished him off with a rain of arrows that killed the poor Drago.
The tragic event caused the other dragons to leave Shu Ling empire. From then on dragons were never seen again. Celestine buried Drago's remains in the palace garden. She would visit her friend every day to ease her guilt. After some weeks, a peculiar plant similar to a cactus, sprouted where Drago's body was buried. It bore fruit with pinkish-red skin and light green scales reminiscent of Drago's feature. Celestine picked one of its fruits and tasted it. It was sweet! Sweet like her friend, Drago.
From then on, it was believed that the plant was Drago. It was called "drago fruit" which later on became dragon fruit.

questions.question: What were the peculiar characteristics of the dragons based on the story?

options.option: They breathed fire and hoarded treasures.

questions.correct_answer: They breathed fire and hoarded treasures.
questions.explanation: The passage explicitly describes dragons as winged, four-legged animals capable of breathing fire and hoarding gold.

questions.question: Why did Drago take the princess to the forbidden cave of treasures?

options.option: He wanted to date the princess.
He got tired of princess's pleading.

questions.explanation: The story states that Drago could not resist the Princess' charm, so he agreed to take her to the forbidden cave.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the emperor?

options.option: He was powerful and a great leader.
He was a loving father to his daughter.

questions.explanation: The emperor's actions and statements about wanting the dragon's treasure reveal his greedy and cunning nature.

questions.question: What made the princess believe that the plant that sprouted was Drago?

options.option: The plant looked like a dragon.
It had fruits which looked like Drago's skin.
It had strong stems similar to Drago's strength.
It had the same smell with Drago's fiery breath.

questions.correct_answer: It had fruits which looked like Drago's skin.
questions.explanation: The passage states that the fruit had pinkish-red skin and light green scales reminiscent of Drago's features.

questions.question: Why do you think the other dragons left the empire?
questions.explanation: This question asks students to infer that the dragons likely left because of the betrayal and killing of two of their kind.

title: Little Octopus
author: Gina Frio-Nobleza
description: a story about kindness despite discrimination
passage:
Everyone went into the classroom as Teacher Stick Fish opened the door. Seahorse, Goldfish, Clam, Oyster and everyone in the class occupied the seats on the first and second rows. Little Octopus, who was an eager learner, wanted to sit in front, but the nasty Goldfish drove her away. "Stay away from us, weirdo," Goldfish uttered. Everyone laughed and joined in discriminating the poor octopus. "Look at her bulbous head, it looks funny!" added the mean Seahorse. "Hey, how does it feel to have those arms? Are you not confused where is left and right?" the Clam taunted her. But Little Octopus was reminded of her mother's word that she should not pick any fight in school and be friendly. She did not say a word and just sat in the last row where no one was seated near her.
Teacher Stick Fish went on with her class when an emergency bell rang. The principal, Sea Turtle, immediately swam around the school campus. "The shark is coming! Proceed to the emergency hideout now!" he announced. But it was too late. The ravenous shark was already in front of them and there was no way to escape. Its big mouth opened, ready to pierce everyone with its sharp teeth and swallow them in an instant. The nasty and mean Goldfish, Seahorse and along with other sea animals in the school screamed and were terrified of their expected death. Suddenly, Little Octopus bravely appeared in front of them and squirted a cloud of dark ink which deterred the extremely hungry shark. Confused, the shark went away.
"Thank you for saving all of us," Mr. Sea Turtle said. "You are indeed our hero, dear," Teacher Stick Fish added. The rest gathered around the Little Octopus and shook her arms. Her classmates, Gold Fish, Oyster and Seahorse went near her and expressed their regret of being rude at her. "We're so sorry. We misjudged you. Thank you for saving our lives!" they exclaimed.
explanation: This story teaches that we should not judge others by their appearance. Little Octopus shows kindness even to those who bullied her, illustrating true heroism and character.

questions.question: Why did nobody like Little Octopus?

options.option: C. He was not a fish.

questions.explanation: In the story, the other sea creatures made fun of Little Octopus's appearance, particularly her 'bulbous head' and multiple arms.

questions.question: Why did the shark go away?

options.option: A. It wanted a bigger prey.
B. The Sea Turtle frightened it.
C. It was afraid of Little Octopus.
D. It was confused by the cloud of black ink.

questions.correct_answer: D. It was confused by the cloud of black ink.
questions.explanation: Little Octopus saved everyone by squirting a cloud of dark ink that confused the shark, causing it to leave.

questions.question: If you were in Octopus' place, would you help those who bullied you? Why?

options.option: A. Yes, because I am brave.
B. No, because they deserve it.
C. No, because the shark is dangerous.
D. Yes, because I am a good person.

questions.correct_answer: D. Yes, because I am a good person.
questions.explanation: The moral of the story suggests that showing kindness even to those who mistreat you is the mark of a good character.

questions.question: Have you experienced bullying? How did you handle it? Share your answers to the class.
questions.explanation: This question asks for personal experiences and reflections, so any thoughtful response is valid.

title: Give thanks
author: Gina Frio-Nobleza
description: a story about gratitude and remembering one's blessings
passage:
Once, there was a poor young boy named Emmanuel. The young boy always loved going to church, together with his mom. Since they were poor, he could not have the things he needed and eat the foods he wanted. Emmanuel had always dreamt of living a comfortable life. Every time he went to church, he prayed to be successful so he could buy all the things he wanted and needed.
Growing up, Emmanuel studied hard and graduated with honors. After graduating from college, he was immediately hired as a manager. Emmanuel never forgot to give thanks to the Lord for slowly granting all his wishes and prayers. Despite his position in the company, he was working on, he still worked very hard until he finally had a company of his own. He was very successful and became one of the richest people in the country. He lived the life he always dreamt of when he was still a poor young boy, but forgot the one who made the success possible for him. He had everything, yet he did not even bother to give thanks to God.
A few months later, Emmanuel's business slowly failed. He got depressed and started blaming the Almighty Father for all the bad things that happened to his life. It was not long when he realized that it was because he forgot the Lord.
One day, with hands clasped together, he entered the church with his faith slowly getting back to its stability. Tears started falling on his face. He stopped walking. In front of the altar, he kneeled. While crying deeply, he heard God's voice saying, "Go back to me, everything is temporary."
On that day, Emmanuel resubmitted himself to the Lord. He realized that he was nothing without the grace of God.
explanation: This story illustrates how gratitude is essential for maintaining success and happiness. Emmanuel learns that acknowledging the source of his blessings is as important as achieving his dreams.

questions.question: What was the dream of Emmanuel?

options.option: A. to have a comfortable life
B. to own a big company
C. to have time with God

questions.correct_answer: A. to have a comfortable life

title: Reddy, the red car
author: Gina Frio-Nobleza
description: a story about pride and learning lessons
passage:
Reddy found a new owner after being displayed in the Show Room for a month. Reddy was a sleek brand new red car. She was the coolest car in town, for she had some features that other cars in the neighborhood did not have-a remote control to start-up, high end stereos, parking cameras, anti-collision warning system, and cool head-up displays. He looked around and thought that other cars were shabby. While he entered the subdivision, everyone greeted him. "Hey, buddy! Welcome!" honked an old model black car, Black Oldie. "You are the coolest car I've seen. Welcome!" admired Bumblebee, the yellow car. "Oh, welcome fella," greeted Silvery, the silver car who puffed a gray cloud of smoke. But, Reddy did not reply. "I don't want to be friends with those ugly and shabby cars," he told himself.
While other cars were friends with each other, Reddy remained solitary. He was confident that he was self-sufficient. His stereos gave him entertainment and his handsome appearance made him feel so confident.
Every day, he would run screeching in high speed while his stereos played to its maximum. Other cars were nervous about Reddy's recklessness and speeding. But they knew that Reddy would not take any advice from them. "One day, he will learn his lesson the hard way," Black Oldie muttered.
One night, Reddy went home drunk. He wobbled on the road and almost hit Bumblebee. "Reddy, are you okay? Please drive slowly!" uttered the concerned yellow car. But Reddy brushed him off. The overly-confident car yelled, "You scruffy car, don't tell me what to do. I am far more high-tech than you!"
Reddy continued to wobble and ran at 160 miles per hour. His anti-collision warning system flashed a red light on his dash board, but he did not notice. He felt dizzy and the vision of the road was blurry to him. He lost control and he whirled horribly, then hit the post. His sleek and shiny body was dilapidated, overly torn and unrecognizable.
Other cars in the neighborhood came and gathered around him. They pitied Reddy for his tragic fate. "Poor Reddy! If only he listened," Bumblebee said. "This is what happened when you are too proud of yourself," muttered Silvery. "Indeed, he learned his lesson the hard way," Oldie Black sighed.
explanation: This story teaches about the dangers of pride and arrogance. Reddy's refusal to listen to others and his excessive confidence ultimately lead to his downfall.

questions.question: What was the reason why Reddy did not befriend the other cars in the neighborhood?

options.option: C. He thought they were shabby.
D. He was irritated of their honking.

questions.correct_answer: C. He thought they were shabby.
questions.explanation: The story states that Reddy thought to himself, 'I don't want to be friends with those ugly and shabby cars.'

questions.question: How would you describe Reddy?
questions.explanation: Throughout the story, Reddy is described as feeling superior to other cars, ignoring their advice, and boasting about being 'far more high-tech.'

questions.question: What did Oldie Black mean when he said that Reddy learned his lesson the hard way?

options.option: B. Reddy knew all the lessons in school.
C. It was difficult to drive when you are drunk.
D. Reddy would only realize things when bad things would happen to him.

questions.correct_answer: D. Reddy would only realize things when bad things would happen to him.
questions.explanation: Oldie Black's statement refers to Reddy having to experience severe consequences before understanding the importance of heeding advice.

questions.question: What could have happened if Reddy listened to the advices of other cars?

options.option: A. The other cars would laugh at him.
B. They would think that he was weak.
C. They would admire his handsome appearance.
D. He would not have experienced the bad things that happened to him.

questions.correct_answer: D. He would not have experienced the bad things that happened to him.
questions.explanation: If Reddy had listened to the other cars' warnings about his reckless driving, he likely would have avoided the accident.

questions.explanation: The story illustrates how Reddy's isolation contributed to his problems, suggesting that life without friends leads to loneliness and lack of support.

title: Mobile Legends
author: Gina Frio-Nobleza
description: a story about gaming addiction and realization
passage:
Archie lay down on his bed with his cell phone held both by his hands. His thumbs briskly and continuously touched the screen as the rainbow-colored lights flickered on his face. His eyes, wide open, almost popped out. He was playing the most popular mobile game, the Mobile Legends.
"An ally has been slain! All troops deployed," his cell phone sounded. "Yehey! I won! I won!" he gladly uttered. It seemed to win in a game was Archie's greatest achievement. It was his daily routine after school to lock himself in his room and play until midnight or sometimes until early morning.
The next day, he would be late in school and showed less interest in his lessons. While his teachers discussed, Archie sat quietly on the chair and stared blankly at the chalkboard. The teacher thought he was listening, but his mind was preoccupied with grunts, gun fires and shouts of heroes in his game.
During recess and lunch breaks, he took out his phone and played instead of feeding himself with nutritious food. He would eat a little and hurriedly went back to playing. He also cut classes just to be home and play his favorite Mobile Legends.
His mother was called by his class adviser on many occasions regarding Archie's worrisome habits in school and about his failing grades, but she didn't know how to stop Archie from playing with his phone.
One day, she picked a hard argument with her son that turned into Archie's angry outburst. It was past midnight when she peered at her son's bedroom. Archie was still awake. He was still playing.
"Archie, turn that off and go to sleep!" she demanded. "I need to finish this mom," Archie insisted.
"No! Give that cell phone to me," she angrily said. But Archie didn't obey his mother. He slammed the door, locked it and shouted something from the inside.
Stunned, her mother cried. "What happened to my son?" she muttered. Archie's father worked abroad and only came home every two years for a two-month vacation. He didn't know about his son's addiction to Mobile Legends because his wife did not tell him for it would be of no help and would only cause her husband to worry too much.
She kneeled down and prayed, "God, what shall I do with my son? Please help me," she sobbed.
Archie fell asleep; his cell phone was in his hand still turned on and logged in to Mobile Legends. The cell phone vibrated and gave off a blinding bright light. All the characters in Mobile Legends went out one by one and started fighting with each other. Archie woke up surprised and ran out from his room, but some of the assassins followed him. They were determined to kill him. "Mother, help me! Help me!" he trembled in fear.
"Archie, wake up. You are dreaming," she said. Archie slowly opened his eyes and hugged his mother. "I am not dreaming mother, they're real. They are here to kill me," Archie was nervous and his body was shaking.
Her mother gently touched his face then said, "Oh darling, you have a high fever. I will bring you to the hospital."
"I don't want to die, mom. Please help me," he whispered. Archie was diagnosed by the doctor with gaming addiction, which is a compulsive mental health disorder that could cause severe damage to one's life. His physical and mental health declined due to skipped meals, stress and insufficient sleep and rest. The doctor advised his mother how to help Archie go back to his old self.
The process would be difficult and long, but Archie's mother was determined to help her poor boy.
explanation: This story highlights the dangers of gaming addiction and its serious impacts on physical and mental health. It shows how addiction can damage family relationships and academic performance.

B. He was fond of playing mobile games.

questions.explanation: The story clearly shows Archie's excessive involvement with Mobile Legends, playing from after school until midnight or early morning.

questions.explanation: This question asks about personal time management strategies, so any thoughtful response is valid.

title: Marian's Secret
author: Gina Frio-Nobleza
description: a story about honesty, guilt, and family understanding
passage:
It was a normal morning for everybody in town. The children played in the backyard and the adults enjoyed a warm plate of breakfast. Despite the good weather and happy children, one child chose to stay inside the house. She sat on her bed and stared at a pile of papers in front of her-all of them marked failed. She began to weep. All of a sudden, she stood up and picked the papers. Enraged, she ripped every piece of paper, one by one.  
"This is horrible! My parents shouldn't know about my poor performance in school!" She continued to sob and threw the pieces of paper in the trash bin.  
"Marian, it's time for breakfast! Please get out of your room and eat," a voice called to her.  
"But Mother, I wish to study," Marian insisted.  
"No buts. Just take your breakfast, honey," her mother replied. Marian pouted, but she had no choice but to obey her mother.  
"Good morning, Marian," Mr. Andrada, Marian's father, greeted her.  
"I hope you are doing well, my dear."  
Mrs. Andrada placed three plates of pancake on the table.  
"I am, Mother," Marian replied.  
"How is school, dear?" her father asked. She froze in fear.  
"What's the matter, Marian? Is there anything wrong?" her concerned mother pat the table softly, while looking at Marian with caring eyes.  
"Is this my punishment for slacking off? I shouldn't have played with other kids too much," she thought to herself.  
"Marian Andrada. Is there something wrong?" Her father slammed his hands on the table, which frightened Marian.  
"Darling, let her think," her mother caressed her father's coarse hands.  
Marian gathered courage to tell the truth to her parents.  
"Mother, Father...," she paused. "I failed in our quarterly exam." She forced herself to admit. The words finally escaped her mouth, guilt rushing over her as her parents' eyes widened.  
"Uum, I'm sorry, for I have disappointed you," Marian pled. The poor young lady expected the worst. Her parents had been very strict with her lately. Surely there is a consequence.  
"Young lady, this is disappointing to hear." She was right, but something unexpected happened.  
"But we understand. You were always in your room, studying your lessons. Of course, you won't have time to meet people. That worried us a lot. So when you asked to play with your friends, I was glad. Glad that you are willing to engage with the others," her father explained.  
"I am so lucky to be your daughter." Marian beamed.  
"We love you dear!" Her father exclaimed.  
"No matter what happens, we will love you from the bottom of our heart. Remember that," her mother assured her. She hugged her parents as tight as she could.  
Now, Marian has more reason to study and do better in school.
explanation: This story explores the themes of honesty, guilt, and parental understanding. It shows that parents often value their child's well-being and honesty more than perfect academic performance.
